newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Reclusive Taleban leader vows to defend Kabul.
newsitem.headline: Reclusive Taleban leader vows to defend Kabul.

text.p: The leader of Afghanistan's radical Islamic Taleban militia vowed on Tuesday to defend Kabul against ousted government forces led by Ahmad Shah Masood.
In his first interview since the Taleban captured Kabul on September 27, Mullah Mohammad Omar dismissed demands of an anti-Taleban alliance for the capital to be demilitarised.
"Our forces are not in Kabul," the 38-year-old leader told the Afghan Islamic Press (AIP) agency. "All our forces are outside, defending the city. Police control security in Kabul."
Omar, wearing a black turban, was sitting in a small room in the southern city of Kandahar, where he has had his headquarters since the Taleban burst on the Afghan scene two years ago.
The Pakistan-based AIP quoted Omar as saying he accepted proposals to form a joint commission comprising Taleban and opposing factions to monitor a ceasefire.
"We don't reject a guarantor role for the United Nations and the Organisation of Islamic Conference," he added.
However, he said his Sunni Moslem militants would fight to hold on to the city they captured on September 27.
"The Rabbani government was illegal and not Islamic, but defended Kabul for several years," he said, referring to ousted President Burhanuddin Rabbani. "We will strongly defend Kabul."
Anti-Taleban factions led by northern Uzbek militia chief General Abdul Rashid Dostum on Tuesday demanded that the capital be demilitarised as a condition for any ceasefire.
Pakistani Interior Minister Naseerullah Babar, who has been trying to broker a truce, said in Islamabad he remained hopeful that a ceasefire agreement could be worked out soon.

Omar urged Rabbani and his allies in the ousted government, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar and Abdurrab Rasul Sayyaf, to give up all government property" -- a reference to military equipment -- and "cut their relations with people who are against Islam".
He appeared to be asking the three men to shun Dostum, a former communist general, but did not name him. He made no mention of Masood, now the Taleban's main battlefield foe.
Omar, who rarely meets visiting dignitaries let alone journalists, said the extent of Dostum's military involvement against the Taleban would become clear in the future.
Dostum has moved forces in support of Masood's men near frontlines north of Kabul, but witnesses say he appears to have stopped short of committing them in battle.

Omar, who lost his right eye while fighting against the former Soviet occupation of Afghanistan, appeared relaxed and confident, reminiscing with his companions about their experiences during the anti-Soviet struggle in the 1980s.

He said the Taleban, seeking to impose a purist version of Islamic Sharia law throughout Afghanistan, were not opposed to education for women, but time and a strong central government were needed before the modalities could be worked out.
"In Islam it is a responsibility for men and women to have knowledge of Islam and we are not against that," he said. "But the ulema (religious scholars) must work out the details."
He said women were needed to work in the medical sector and some other areas which he did not specify.
The Taleban have drawn international criticism since their seizure of Kabul for actions that have effectively banned most women from working and most girls from going to school.
Omar said the Taleban, or religious scholars originally recruited at Islamic colleges in Pakistan, were opposed to the narcotics trade, but could not immediately ban opium-growing.
"We have already ordered that there should be no hashish in the country and have destroyed several heroin factories in Spin Boldak and Chattu (near the Pakistani border)," he said.

He said he had ordered the Taleban to stop large-scale movement of opium on main roads, but added: "We cannot stop opium-growing now, though we are against it. We must go step by step because the people are poor and they need an alternative."
Afghanistan is the world's leading producer of raw opium, from which heroin is made, and has also gained a reputation as a haven for armed Islamic militants from around the Moslem world.
"Islam does not want people to be killed," Omar said. "If someone enters a country with that country's permission, it does not give him the right to kill people or set off bombs."
"We allow refugees in our country, but do not give any military training," he added. "But as an Islamic movement, we support all oppressed Moslems in the world."
